G.L. c. 186.proposition: Defendant Michael Thompson is an individual who, upon information and belief, owns, operates, manages, and/or controls the residential rental property located at 45 Broadway Street, Chelsea, Suffolk County, Massachusetts (the “Premises”), and is Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of Massachusetts landlord-tenant law, including G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201321.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–21, because the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Chelsea Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 239, § 2, because the Premises are located in Chelsea, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred in this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Chelsea Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 239, § 2, because the Premises are located in Chelsea, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred in this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: General Laws c. 186, § 14 provides in relevant part that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant,” and that a landlord who does so is liable for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.”

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Landlords in Massachusetts are also obligated to maintain rental premises, including common areas and building entryways, in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and basic standards of safety and habitability.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain secure common areas also violates the landlord’s obligation to keep the premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, and such violations are evidence of breach of quiet enjoyment and habitability.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes a covenant of quiet enjoyment, both by statute and common law.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly assumes and applies an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential tenancies, but it does not discuss its origins or state that it arises "both by statute and common law." The case focuses on constructive eviction and the landlord’s breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment due to noise from a lounge; it does not cite G.L. c. 186, § 14 or otherwise distinguish statutory versus common-law sources. Thus it supports that there is an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, but not the specific proposition about dual statutory and common-law bases.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). … Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes a covenant of quiet enjoyment, both by statute and common law.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that every tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and describes that covenant as arising from common law. It also discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14, which statutorily protects tenants’ quiet enjoyment and expands remedies, thereby recognizing both a common-law and statutory basis for quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts residential tenancies.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy…. Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 283 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to use and enjoy the premises without substantial interference attributable to the landlord’s acts or omissions, including the landlord’s failure to take reasonable steps to address conditions under his control that foreseeably cause substantial interference.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The court expressly defines the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting freedom from serious interference with the tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions, focusing on what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done. It further holds that the landlord may be liable where it fails to take reasonable, relatively easy measures to remove unlawful actors from premises under its control, when their presence seriously interferes with tenants’ use and enjoyment. This directly matches the proposition that quiet enjoyment covers substantial interference attributable to the landlord’s failure to address foreseeable conditions under its control.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions… if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: Landlords in Massachusetts are also obligated to maintain rental premises, including common areas and building entryways, in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and basic standards of safety and habitability.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: The opinion, even though in a concurrence/dissent, expressly states that the State Sanitary Code (which has the force of law) imposes on owners the obligation to comply with minimum standards of fitness for human habitation and that this burden is on the owner of rented dwelling units. It further argues that renting a dwelling unit carries an implied agreement that the unit complies with those legal standards and that the landlord will do what the law requires during the term. This directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts landlords must maintain rental premises, including common areas and entryways, in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and basic habitability/safety standards.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation… It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units.… I would… hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards…”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court has recognized that serious security defects and failures to protect tenants from foreseeable criminal or disruptive intrusions can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment where they materially impair the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns whether a strict-liability violation of the lead paint statute, without proof of landlord fault, automatically constitutes a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. The SJC holds that at least negligent conduct and foreseeability are required and discusses prior quiet-enjoyment cases (including some involving defects and security), but it does not itself recognize that serious security failures or failures to protect tenants from foreseeable criminal or disruptive intrusions constitute a breach. Those principles, if any, come from other cited cases (e.g., Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority), not from Al‑Ziab’s holding.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: In Cruz, we observed that the landlord had notice of the defects in the leased premises which it failed to repair, and that it was “wholly foreseeable” that the injury to the tenant would result from this failure to make the repairs. Indeed, in each case since the 1973 statutory revision in which we have recognized a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, there was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Plaintiff’s situation is distinguishable from minor inconveniences; rather, it involves ongoing security breaches and the fear of crime in the home, which Massachusetts courts have recognized as serious interferences with quiet enjoyment.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss security breaches, fear of crime, or interference with quiet enjoyment as such. It mentions inadequate door locks only as one of several sanitary code violations and then explicitly characterizes most conditions as having “minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment,” allowing the judge to disregard minor violations. The case is about warranty of habitability, rent control, security deposits, and utilities, not about recognizing security-related conditions as serious interferences with quiet enjoyment.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Several violations of the State Sanitary Code…have existed in the tenant’s apartment… The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.”

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain secure common areas also violates the landlord’s obligation to keep the premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, and such violations are evidence of breach of quiet enjoyment and habitability.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The case clearly ties the landlord’s contractual/warranty obligations to compliance with the State Sanitary Code and treats substantial Sanitary Code violations (e.g., lack of heat and hot water) as rendering the premises uninhabitable and supporting rent abatement. However, it does not address security of common areas, nor does it discuss quiet enjoyment; its focus is the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement, not security-related duties. Thus it supports the link between Sanitary Code violations and habitability, but not the specific proposition about security of common areas or quiet enjoyment.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The State Sanitary Code, not such usage, provides the proper yardstick for measuring the landlord’s conduct. The Hemingway court removed the landlord’s duties under the Code from the realm of private ordering. … Those duties cannot be waived, bargained away, or qualified by customary practice.”

*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.raw_text: *Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp.*, 340 Mass. 124, 127–28 (1959)
*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, when a landlord fails to remedy dangerous or seriously defective conditions within a reasonable time after notice, that failure is attributable to the landlord and supports liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.case_name: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp.
*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns common-law constructive eviction and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in a commercial lease; it does not involve, cite, or interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court discusses material breach and constructive eviction where a landlord fails to provide essential services, but it never frames that failure as statutory liability under c. 186, § 14 or discusses ‘dangerous or seriously defective conditions’ in the sense used in that statute. Accordingly, it cannot be relied on as authority for the specific statutory proposition stated.
*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.relevant_excerpt: “Such a failure constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment … and ‘enables the lessee to recover the damages caused to him thereby and also provides the lessee with the defense of “constructive eviction” (if he removes from the premises).’ … We perceive no reason why equitable relief, in appropriate circumstances, should not be given by way of (1) a declaration … that the wrongful acts of the lessor justify treating those acts as a constructive eviction, (2) appropriate consequential relief, and (3) assessment of damages.”

*Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, when a landlord fails to remedy dangerous or seriously defective conditions within a reasonable time after notice, that failure is attributable to the landlord and supports liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The court specifically applies G.L. c. 186, § 14 to a landlord’s long‑term failure to correct serious, known code violations and holds that such omissions constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The opinion emphasizes that the landlord’s omissions that allow serious code violations to persist for years constitute ‘acts or omissions’ impairing the value of the premises and that there is no good faith defense, thereby attributing the failure to remedy dangerous conditions to the landlord for § 14 liability.
*Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to be free from ‘serious’ interferences with their tenancies. See G. L. c. 186, § 14… A landlord violates G. L. c. 186, § 14, when its ‘acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.’… Here, the judge found that the landlord knowingly rented the premises in a defective condition and failed to correct the ventilation problem — a serious code violation — for over nine years… we think that the judge was required to find a serious interference with the tenancy and substantial impairment of the character and value of the leased premises.”}
